qas.question: Aside from her choice of Eden's successor, what crisis caused Elizabeth to be criticized?
What did Lord Altrincham accuse Elizabeth of being?
Who did Elizabeth appoint as Prime Minister after the resignation of Macmillan?
When was a formal mechanism for electing the Minister adopted?
In what year did Lord Altrincham begin to own a newspaper?
Who was one of the prominent people who criticized Elizabeth for appointing the Earl of Home as prime minister?
In what year did Lord Altrincham die?
How many ministers did Elizabeth consult before naming Eden as the prime minister?
In what year did the Earl of Home receive his title?

context: The <a0_0>Suez crisis<a0_0/> and the choice of Eden's successor led in <b5_0><b9_0>1957<b9_0/><b5_0/> to the first major personal criticism of the Queen. In a magazine, which he owned and edited, <b6_0>Lord Altrincham<b6_0/> accused her of being "<a1_0>out of touch<a1_0/>". Altrincham was denounced by public figures and slapped by a member of the public appalled by his comments. Six years later, in <a2_0>1963<a2_0/>, Macmillan resigned and advised the Queen to appoint the <a3_0>Earl of Home<a3_0/> as prime minister, advice that she followed. The Queen again came under criticism for appointing the prime minister on the advice of a small number of ministers or <b8_0>a single minister<b8_0/>. In <a4_0><b7_0>1965<b7_0/><a4_0/>, the Conservatives adopted a formal mechanism for electing a leader, thus relieving her of involvement.
